author: Sanjana Dubey
title: Spain’s Unparalleled Destination: Córdoba’s October Weather Reaches A Stunning 27°C
text:
The Andalusian region in Spain boasts numerous stunning destinations, each one captivating enough to enchant visitors.
Seville is famous for its vibrant energy and breathtaking architecture, while Malaga offers stunning beaches, a wealth of cultural experiences, and a lively nightlife. Granada features the iconic Alhambra, a spectacular palace and fortress celebrated as one of the most significant examples of Islamic architecture.
However, amidst this remarkable collection of cities lies Córdoba—a delightful destination that frequently goes unnoticed.
Córdoba, recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, boasts a deep historical legacy, with its origins tracing back to Roman times in 152 BC. Visitors can still explore traces of its rich past throughout the city today.
In the 10th century, Córdoba served as the capital of the Moorish Empire during the ‘Islamic Golden Age.’ During this period, the city thrived as a hub for art, science, and philosophy, establishing itself as one of the most sophisticated cities in Europe.
Today, Córdoba is frequently overlooked in favor of more famous Andalusian locations. However, those who venture here will discover breathtaking architecture and a vibrant cultural landscape, featuring the impressive Mezquita-Cathedral, the historic Roman bridge, and the charming alleys of the Jewish quarter.
Córdoba has even earned a spot in Skyscanner’s annual list of the most sought-after destinations for 2025.
It ranked fifth among locations that have experienced the most significant rise in searches in the past year, joining other remarkable places like Tromsø in Norway and Siem Reap in Cambodia.
While we’ve already highlighted Córdoba’s appeal, here’s everything you should know before you finalize your travel plans to this Andalusian gem.
Getting to Córdoba: Your Travel Guide
The closest airport to Córdoba is in Seville, approximately 130 kilometers (81 miles) southwest of the city.
From Seville, travelers have various options for reaching Córdoba. Renting a car allows for a scenic drive of about 90 minutes. Alternatively, a direct train ride takes between 45 minutes to an hour.
Several airlines, including Ryanair, EasyJet, and British Airways, offer direct flights from London to Seville. The flight duration is roughly two hours and 45 minutes, with ticket prices starting at around £45 in late October, according to Skyscanner.
Another option is to fly into Malaga Airport, located about 165 kilometers (103 miles) from Córdoba. Direct flights from London to Malaga take approximately two hours and 40 minutes and can be more budget-friendly, with fares starting at just £20 in October, according to Skyscanner.
The journey from Malaga to Córdoba is comparable in time; driving takes around one hour and 45 minutes, while direct train services cover the distance in roughly 50 minutes.
Córdoba’s Climate: What to Expect
The ideal time to visit Córdoba is in the spring (April to early June) or during the autumn months (September to October), when the weather is mild and perfect for exploring the city in comfort.
As an inland city in southern Spain, Córdoba experiences more intense temperatures compared to coastal regions, with its summers often reaching scorching and uncomfortable levels.
For this reason, it’s best to avoid visiting between July and August, as temperatures often climb above 40°C.
October is an excellent alternative, offering cooler but still warm weather, with temperatures reaching up to 27°C—ideal for those looking to soak up some late-season sun.
Winter in Córdoba is also enjoyable, with mild temperatures ranging from 10-16°C and fewer tourists, making it perfect for those seeking a quieter experience away from the crowds.
Top Things to Do in Córdoba
Córdoba, with its UNESCO World Heritage designation, is rich in history and culture, offering countless attractions for visitors.
No trip to the city would be complete without exploring the Mezquita Cathedral, hailed by Lonely Planet as one of the “world’s most remarkable examples of Islamic architecture.”
Initially constructed as a mosque in the 8th century, the Mezquita was transformed into a Christian cathedral in the 13th century.
It showcases distinctive horseshoe arches with red and white stripes, a prayer hall adorned with carved columns, and an exquisitely designed mihrab.
With over 23,300 reviews on Tripadvisor, the Mezquita boasts a five-star rating, with visitors frequently describing it as “magnificent.”
Córdoba is also home to numerous Roman landmarks, with the most striking being the Roman Bridge of Córdoba. Initially constructed in the 1st century BC during the reign of Emperor Augustus, it remains an iconic symbol of the city’s ancient history.
Though it has seen numerous renovations throughout its history, much of the Roman Bridge’s original structure remains preserved. Visitors on Tripadvisor have praised it as both “marvelous” and “fascinating,” highlighting its timeless appeal.
